section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 4: Vehicles at Work

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children if they ever wanted something for a gift but got something else instead. How did they feel?
Invite children to act like firefighters putting out a fire to build excitement for reading A Fire Truck Named Red.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we’re going to read A Fire Truck Named Red. This book was written by Randall de Sève and illustrated by Bob Staake.
Scout enjoys all sorts of books, but he especially likes narratives about fire trucks.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
Why was Rowan sad at the beginning of the story?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Rowan want for his birthday? Let’s find out if he gets it or not.
What did Rowan get for his birthday? What does it look like?
Do you think Rowan will like his birthday gift? Why? Why not? (MB)
Rowan’s grandfather told Rowan about Red the fire truck. He said, “No blaze was too big, no rescue too small for Red and me.”
Look at Rowan’s face. How do you think he feels about his gift? Why? (MB)
Look at the picture. What are Papa and Red doing? How do you play with your toys? Do you ever imagine you are doing things like Papa and Red?
Papa said, “Red and I rushed to the scene!”
Why do you think they had to get there so quickly?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
Why was Rowan sad at the beginning of the story?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He wanted a new fire truck and he got Papa’s old truck instead.
Red was not a shiny new fire truck.
Red didn’t have lights that flashed.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about Red as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did Rowan want a new fire truck or Papa’s old fire truck?
Rowan wanted a new fire tr_____ (truck).
Rowan wanted a new fire truck.
How do you know that Rowan was sad?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning to deal with disappointment helps children develop coping skills and emotional resilience. You can help children by labeling your own emotions (e.g., when you feel frustrated or tired) and by helping children identify and describe their own emotions. Teach children to take deep breaths when they are feeling sad or disappointed.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Take Another Perspective
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about a time when children had to understand another person’s perspective or point of view about something. How did they try to understand how the other person was feeling? Explain that when we take another perspective we learn to think about how someone else is feeling.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book A Fire Truck Named Red written by Randall de Sève and illustrated by Bob Staake. We will talk about others’ feelings.
Clifford like narratives like his one because he gets to learn about another person’s perspective.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about the take another perspective Mind Builder.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Papa is excited to tell Rowan about his adventures with Red the fire truck. What is Rowan’s point of view about Red?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit point of view Vocabulary Card.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do you think you would feel if you got Red as a present? (MB)
Papa told Rowan that he and Red used to be a great team. What do you think Papa means?
Even though Rowan is sad about not getting a new fire truck for his birthday, he still knew how to be polite.
Why do you think Rowan was being polite to his Papa? (MB)
Why do you think Rowan can hear Red’s siren now? Why can he see Red’s lights? Is he changing his perspective? Is he starting to understand Papa’s point of view? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Have children play “Be a Perspective Detective.” Have children form pairs. Then have them ask what their partners’ favorite and least favorite toys are. Then have each child ask their partner why they like or do not like that particular toy. Children can then share their perspectives about the toy their partner likes or dislikes. You can provide sentence starters, for example: Badou’s favorite toy is _________. He likes this toy because ________. I understand why Badou likes this toy because _________.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about what they learned about a partner’s perspective.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: You can teach children to recognize their own perspective and the perspective of others by emphasizing how a character feels in read aloud texts. Help children learn to recognize a character’s perspective, or how he thinks and feels, and compare it to their own perspective. (Weis/fortheloveofteachers.com, 2017)

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When a book reminds you of your own life, you make a connection.

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children pretend they are firefighters rescuing a cat from a tall tree. What will they use to rescue the cat? Will the cat kick and claw? Will they return the cat to its owner?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to reread the book A Fire Truck Named Red written by Randall de Sève and illustrated by Bob Staake.
This story is about a boy and his fire truck. Scout loves stories about fire trucks!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
When Papa was a little boy, what did he imagine doing with Red?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Rowan wants a fire truck for his birthday. He wants a fire truck that has “lights that flash and a siren that wails.”
Rowan wants the siren to wail so that it can be loud. Why would he want it to be loud?
Can you describe the truck Rowan got for his birthday? What did it look like? How did Rowan feel? Why? (MB)
What did Papa and Red have to do to help the elephants?
Red and Papa rushed to the scene again.
What did they have to do this time?
Look at the pictures on these pages. What did Papa and Red save?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question.
When Papa was a little boy, what did he imagine doing with Red?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He imagined giving elephants a bath.
He imagined putting out a blaze at the library.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about what Papa imagined he did with Red when he was a boy.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did Papa imagine he rescued a cat or a dog?
Papa imagined that he rescued a c____ (cat).
Papa imagined that he rescued a cat.
Why do you think Papa had to use his imagination?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help children learn words to express their feelings in English by modeling words such as disappointed, comfortable, relaxed, happy, unhappy, worried, confused, embarrassed, and ashamed. Multilingual preschoolers are learning these words in their home language, too.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 4: Vehicles at Work

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about different vehicles. Ask if they move on land, on water, or in air. Ask children if the vehicles move fast or slow. Then ask what each vehicle can do.
Have children act out the following: rowing a boat, driving a car and honking the horn, flying a plane, and riding a bicycle.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Wheels on the Bus. It is an informational text in the form of a poster.
Scout loves songs about vehicles in his neighborhood.
A Fire Truck Named Red and The Wheels on the Bus are both about vehicles. Let’s find more connections between the two!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Vehicles at Work
section.rac_body-text: Point out the different vehicles on the front of the Big Chart as you read the text. Use the prompts to introduce each vehicle. Then have children sing along with you.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can come point to the bus? What kind of bus is this?
The engine on the train makes it go.
What sound does the engine make?
Who can come point to the wings on the plane?
What vehicles did Rowan see in the toy store window?
How does a digger help us? Move your arms like a digger!

section.rac_body-text: Have children build different vehicles using different shapes. They can use circles for the wheels of a truck, or car, or bus, and squares and rectangles for the body of the vehicle. They can use triangles for sails on a sailboat or wings on a plane. Have children explain which vehicle they made and the shapes they used.
Provide a writing prompt about vehicles and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Most multilingual learners will know the names of many vehicles, such as a car, a boat, a bus, and an airplane, in their home language. Encourage children to teach the rest of the class the names of two vehicles in their home language.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 4: Vehicles at Work

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children reenact the following scenes from A Fire Truck Named Red: Rowan looking in the toy store window; Papa giving Red to Rowan; Rowan’s reaction when he got Red instead of a new truck; Rowan starting to get excited about Red when his papa talks about the elephants; and hosing down the elephants at the circus. Encourage children to say what they’re doing and how Rowan was feeling.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book A Fire Truck Named Red written by Randall de Sève and illustrated by Bob Staake.
This book is a narrative. That means it’s a story that the author made up in his mind. Scout loves to read narratives.
This week we read about a boy who got a birthday gift from his grandfather. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What did Rowan think about Red at the end of the story?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you see in these pictures? What is the elephant doing to Papa with it’s trunk? Pretend you are an elephant. Use your arm like a trunk.
Papa said that he and Red returned to the station to refill Red’s tanks.
Why would they need to refill the tanks?
Look at the pictures on these pages. What do you notice? Point to Rowan. Is he in Papa’s story? How do you know?
Now that Rowan is in Papa’s story, he can “see Red’s lights, the fog, the traffic.”
How do you feel when you are stuck in traffic? Show me the face you would make if you were stuck in traffic.
Look at Rowan’s face now. How do you think he feels about Red now? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk with a partner about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Rowan think about Red at the end of the story?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Rowan was happy to see Red.
Rowan thought he and Red could be a great team.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how Rowan felt about Red at the end of the story.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Was Rowan happy or sad to see Red?
Rowan was h_____ (happy) to see Red.
Rowan was happy to see Red.
How did Rowan change his perspective about Red?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Learning About Animal Parts
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Encourage children to talk about the parts of different animals, such as the elephant’s trunk. Ask children to name other animal parts, such as wings, beaks, claws, horns, fur, feathers, legs, scales, tails, and fins. Check children’s understanding of each body part. Encourage children to sort animals based on different body parts.
